span: Alright, let's take a look at the next one.
Option A, it has four triangles upright, one tilted.
Option B, all of them are upright, and the sun [star] is lit up.
summary: Notes upright triangles and star in B

span: Option C, the sun is down [the star is not lit up], and there's one big triangle that's slightly…slanted.
summary: Observes star absence and slanted big triangle in C

span: Option D has no sun [star not lit up], and there's one triangle that's to its side.
summary: Notes star absence and sideways triangle in D

span: Option E has a couple to their side.
And Option F, there's no sun [star], and there's a couple to the side.
summary: Observes F lacks star and has sideways triangles

span: So, if I had to infer something, the one similarity that sticks out is in the ones where the sun [star] is lit up, the green triangles all seem to be upright.
The blue ones are slanted in E and A, but not B, so there's nothing there and they share no similarities in terms of the red triangles, since option E doesn't even have any.
summary: Rejects blue and red similarity possibilities

span: So, I guess one of the rules would be it has to include a green triangle.
Um… seems to be different sizes, so option E has three, other option A and B have two.
summary: Counts size categories across starred panels

span: So, I think maybe a rule is it has to have a mini triangle and a bigger triangle… in them, if I had to guess.
I don't see any other rule besides that, since they don't share a similarity in red and blue.
summary: Commits to size rule over color rules

span: Also, there's no real similarities, I think.
So, that would be my guess: that there has to be a small and a bigger triangle upright.
Okay, okay. Let’s see.
Panels A, B, and E are lit up.
What do they have in similarity? What do they have in disparity?
Okay, count the number of cones first.
Panel A has one, two, three, four, five.
Panel B has one, two, three, four, five.
Panel E has—wait, is that separate cone? No— one, two, three, four, five.
summary: Counts cones in E with check

span: So they all have five cones each.
Panel C also has [counting] five.
Okay, so it’s not the number rule for that.
It’s not a case of whether all the cones are upright or not, because panels A and E have cones that are sideways.
Does it have something to do with the color of the cones?
Uh No… every panel has an assortment of each color, except for E, which is missing red, but that is irrelevant to the rule.
It’s not about all cones being up or down either.
[MUMBLING] Number of cones — no, they’re all five. Yes, they’re all five.
summary: Revisits old rule smd reaffirms counting rule invalid

span: What is the hidden rule here?
Wait… is it that…okay, no it is not the number of green cones either.
Two… two… one… two… two… one… three… two… no.
Okay, so it’s not about the number of colors either.
What is the rule here?
That they’re all standing up? No. That they’re all sideways? No. That some of them… no.
[SIGHS] I cannot figure out the rule here.
Is it the ratio of colors? (6.0)
Two to one… two to one… three to two… three to zero…
no, that’s not it either.
I cannot figure it out.
In this one, panels A, B, and E have special rules. C, D, and F do not.
Let’s see… (5.0)
Panels A, B, and E, all the green triangles are pointing up.
summary: Observes upright green triangles in starred

span: And panel… (10.0) Oh boy.
There are little green triangles in A, B, and E, and there are also little green triangles in all of them…um, no.
There's one little purple [blue] triangle in the rule, when the rule was applied….
Oh no, that’s in D too.
There’s one, two, three little triangles in the rule box.
Maybe that’s the rule, three little triangles, I guess.
Okay, we have another one.
A, B, and E are the ones with commonalities [they follow the rule]. Panels C, D, and F don’t.
So let’s start with panel A.
summary: Announces focus on panel A first

span: What do we have? One, two, three, four, five triangles.
Panel B, [counting] we have five triangles.
Panel E, we have [counting] five triangles.
So that’s a commonality.
Panel C also has five triangles. Panel D also has five triangles. And panel F has five triangles as well,
so the number of triangles is not the rule.

The color rule doesn’t apply here either, because panel A has red, blue, and green, but some of the ones that don’t fit the rule, like panel C, have red, blue, and green as well. So that doesn’t seem to be that either.
Let’s look at upright triangles, that was something we considered last time.
Panel A has [counting] four upright triangles.
Panel B has five upright triangles.
So it’s not that either.
Uh… this one’s more difficult.
Let’s look at the pattern.
Pattern of panel A is arranged green, blue, red, blue, green, so they are… none of the same colors repeated.
Um and it mirrors: as in green, blue, red, blue, green. So that’s something we can look for.
But panel B doesn’t mirror in that way, red, red, green, blue, green.
Um… Let’s look at ones outside the rule, panel C, panel D, panel E, I’m not sure.
I can’t find any commonalities here. I’m struggling with this.
In terms of locations, they’re scattered. It’s not like the matching ones are only on the left. That doesn’t seem to apply either.
Um I don’t have much confidence here in any of them.
I think the most likely explanation is something that I did not have time to consider, which is that…um, maybe they have the… the same number of…
Oh wait, just a quick check of the number of… No, it’s not that.
I think it might have something to do with the area of the triangles? That’s a wild guess, and I’m sure it won’t be that.
[TYPING] Other things I could maybe consider is maybe the number of large triangles. And that would be based on height…
I don’t have an answer for this one, I’m afraid.
So A, B, and E… A, B, and E...
So it's not a red cone, it's not a large green cone or a large blue cone.
But it could be a small green cone and a small blue cone...because C, D, and F do not have one small green and one small blue.
summary: Proposes small green & blue cone rule

span: So that is my answer. And I'm locking it in. (9.0)
Yeah, I can't see any other reason, because C...C doesn't have a red...oh, sorry, doesn't have a blue or green small cone.
D also does not have a blue or green small cone.
And F only has a green small cone, so it needs a blue small cone before the light will be lit.
[TYPING] You need at least one small blue cone and one small green cone.
